Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: While traveling, only a small vendor known to be kosher-certified is within reach for the next meal.
Story:
I was finishing up a trim for Mrs. Klein, one of my favorite regulars, when she glanced in the mirror and smiled. “Could you just take a little more off the fringe?” she asked, her tone gentle. I nodded, reaching for my scissors, but my stomach rumbled—reminding me I hadn’t eaten since morning. I glanced at the clock. My next client was due soon, and I’d only have a short break. 

Normally, I’d grab a quick bite from the café next door, but today, I was in an unfamiliar part of town. The only kosher-certified vendor I’d found was a good ten-minute walk away, and I’d barely have time to get there and back before my next appointment. If I took extra time perfecting Mrs. Klein’s fringe, I’d have to skip lunch or break my kosher observance. If I rushed, I might disappoint her, something I always tried to avoid as a hairdresser. The weight of both roles pressed on me—my commitment to my clients, and my commitment to my faith—each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
